When I was 11 years old we moved to Texas and at that time I had been writing a little poetry for a couple years. The first summer we moved to Texas we didn't know anyone and didn't know any place to go and my father parked me and my brother at a boys club, Panther Boys Club in Fort Worth, Texas. Absolutely hooked. And then science fiction reading formed probably on the average about 50% of my recreational reading for the rest of my life, to this stage anyway. segments.text: I'll ask you first of all Warren just give us a little bit about your background, kind
of how you grew up and what might have influenced you to be a writer and why a science fiction
writer.
When I was 11 years old we moved to Texas and at that time I had been writing a little
poetry for a couple years.
The first summer we moved to Texas we didn't know anyone and didn't know any place to go
and my father parked me and my brother at a boys club, Panther Boys Club in Fort Worth,
Texas.
It was a blockbuster summer for Texas.
They were trying to bust the top out of the thermometer.
There was no air conditioning in the Panther Boys Club.
We used to go down there, a pair of cut-off blue jeans shorts, no shirt, no shoes, no socks,
brown bag lunch and a quarter for a Coke, right?
And that was it.
The only cool place in the building was the north side of the building in the library,
which had a cement floor.
It was the only cool spot in the building and I loved to read and went to the library
and all along the bottom shelf of the library was Tom Swift and Tom Swift, Jr.
And that summer I read them all, went back to school in the fall, discovered Space Cadet
by Robert Heinlein and I was hooked.
Absolutely hooked.
And then science fiction reading formed probably on the average about 50% of my recreational reading
for the rest of my life, to this stage anyway.
I started trying to write stories that may or may not have been science fiction or horror
or occult after about the seventh grade when a teacher read in two parts at Gran Poe's
Cask of Amontillado.
And for years I turned out terribly Poe-esque, grotesque, horror, gore stories.
Which weren't any good, but which were great fun, which were great fun, were great fun to turn in in class.
You know, you have to write, a teacher would say, write a page of description and I write this lurid scene of grotesque, you know, body in the grave, Edgar Allan Poe description.
I guess it was great early training for doing that.
I didn't start trying seriously to write science fiction until about 1977, 1978.
And thought, you know, I've been reading so much of this, I really ought to try writing some of it.
I had written a war novel, which is unpublishable.
It's written in seven different styles.
But it was the first novel that I wrote, so I decided to write this science fiction novel.
And discovered how little I knew about, intuitively, about the storytelling process.
That the writing had always been very easy for me, but how little intuitively I knew about the storytelling process.
And so I forced myself to finish that terrible book.
It has an abbreviated ending.
I finally decided that, you know, the bomb would blow up and they would all disappear because I couldn't cope with them anymore.
But I forced myself to finish it.
And then I tried my hand at some fantasy because I was reading a fair amount of fantasy at the time and decided that I really like science fiction better.
So when I got the opportunity to quit my full-time job and only have to work part-time and write for a year,
which was a contract my wife and I agreed to.
And I said, you know, I'm going to give it my best shot in science fiction.
And this is the genre that I've loved, so I might as well do everything I can to make it work.
And that's where the Windhover books came from.
Okay, I've got to ask.
It's the Windhover books.
The hero's name is Gerard Manley.
I'm not an English major, but...
The clues are pretty evident.
It is.
That's slightly reminiscent of something.
And this was obviously deliberate.
Are you interested in Hopkins, the poet?
Yeah, it's my left-handed salute to the old man.
I mean, I think he was a poet who was probably 100 years ahead of his time.
He's not one of those poets that you walk around reciting verses to at people's parties.
But I think he did marvelous.
I think he took marvelous chances with the language and marvelous chances with poetry.
And some of it is just, you know, it's breathtaking.
But no one's going to read a tribute to Gerard Manley Hopkins.
So when I sat down to do the story, I had already decided that I was going to name the ship Windhover, which is his most famous poem, The Windhover.
And it just seemed, you know, the natural thing to do, the name of the character Gerard Manley, especially since he is interested in poetry, right?
And then in the second book, when Gerard finds himself at the end of his road and thinks this is going to be it, it's going to be all over, he writes a poem to GM, which is himself, right?
But it's also the poem to Gerard Manley Hopkins.
And it echoes the language of the wind hover, Hopkins, the wind hover.
It echoes that language and asks some of the same questions only from Gerard's point of view rather than from Hopkins' point of view.
So, yeah, it's all very intentional.
I mean, with 54-hour minor in English, it's hard to be unintentional about things like that.
This is kind of, it's a cheap shot.
I read that.
Viet Cong took cheaper ones.
I enjoyed it.
Yeah.
What about, you know, all the 15-year-old kids that read for four hours and toss the book?
You know, I guess basically the question is to what audience do you write or do you write for yourself?
I think, I think it was Raymond Chandler, but I'm, I, I'm not sure who said that I write first to entertain myself and hope that others are entertained.
I had a certain audience awareness in that when I went back and did the second draft, I simplified the language somewhat from the original draft because I thought I had gotten too carried away.
But I didn't write it thinking of a specific audience.
Whereas in the, in the book that Ralph and I wrote together, we were, we were aiming in a sense at an audience that starts with those 12, 13, 14-year-olds.
We wanted to pick up the space opera buffs and then also write things for, you know, the older audience at the same time, trying to do both things at the same time.
And it was a way of stretching to be able to, to do both, to keep the language simple and yet to deal with complex ideas and keep the story moving.
So that if you didn't want to deal with the complex ideas, you could just go through the story.
But for those books, I really didn't have an audience in mind.
It was just a story that I had been thinking about for eight or nine months and I wanted to tell.
And I, that seemed more important.
And then when I made the decision about how to tell the story, I knew without deliberating on it a great deal that I had limited my audience.
But I thought, well, I'm willing to take the chance because I figured I needed something to break into the market.
And I think you have to take chances to do that.
It was much appreciated.
I really enjoyed it.
I, I, I'm glad that you stuck to your guns.
This seems like as good a place as any to, to ask this question on, on the back of an image of voices.
There's a quote from Ann McCaffrey out in Onaborn's ambitions for four years.
So what was your relationship with Ann McCaffrey and had you corresponded with her?
I was a book salesman for Ballantyne.
Ballantyne Del Rey did the McCaffrey Dragon books, among others.

And when she did the first promotion tour around the country for the hardcover edition of, of White Dragon, I cornered the Del Rey direct salesman and said, if you don't get her into some of my wholesale accounts, you know, you're going to, I'm going to break your knees.
Besides, I want to meet her.
I mean, there's other reasons besides.
So I got her in, I think, three of the accounts.
And then we took her to the airport together.
And her plane was an hour and a half late.
So we sat in the, in the bar in the airport drinking Coors beer, which is one of her favorites.
And she can't get in, in Ireland and listening to Annie tell stories, which is a marvelous experience in and of itself.
So when she came back the following year for the paperback tour for White Dragon, my wife and I picked her up at the airport, took her to the hotel in Dallas, which was on fire at the time.
So that was all very exciting.
She was extremely tired.
It was the 23rd day of a 28 day tour and night, you know, in 31 cities or something like that.
And she was beginning.
So we ended up staying until like one or two o'clock in the morning because she couldn't sleep and just talking and chatting.
And then I took her around all the next day with a case of Coors beer ice down in the back and about three melons all diced up because you can't get fresh melon and ironed either.
Right.

So she munched on melon and drank Coors beer all day while we toured Dallas and Fort Worth and visited bookstores and radio stations and developed a grand rapport and ended up at the airport drinking Coors beer and having a wonderful time.
So we corresponded then, you know.
Fairly regularly.
Fairly regularly.
I say fairly regularly three or four times a year after that.
And after I'd finished the book and Bannam had bought it, they said, you know, who do you know?
And I said, well, the author I know best is Anne McCaffrey.
So I asked her, I said, you know, would you, would you read it?
And she said, yes.
And then she said those wonderful things.
And I don't remember anything for about a week after getting that letter.
You know, it's lonely.
Yes, yes, yes.
It was, it was, the, Annie's letter was, was as much of a high as the sale.
Right.
Right.
Yeah.
It was as much of a high as the sale was itself.
Right.
Right.
The, the format that you use in the two books is, it's like a diary.
And then you've got this internal dialogue.
How did you develop that approach?
Years of talking to myself.
Yes.
That, that, that's really it.
I mean, I, I know a lot of writers who talk to themselves, who, when they sit at the typewriter,
talk, carry on conversations and go down the road by themselves in the car and carry on
conversations with themselves, work out problems that way.
And I thought, there's so much of me in Gerard, although there's a great deal of Gerard that
isn't me, there's so much of me in him that it just seemed natural given what had happened
to him to let him do this same thing, except to make it a little more formal and have him
address himself as self.
Part of that is, part of how that happened to him is explained in the third book.
What brought him to that point where he really began to talk to himself?
That's how he got that quote unquote self-reliance, right, is explained in the third book because
of what happened to him in the missing 10 years, right?
Can't give away the plot now.
Okay.
Because the next question, I had the quote from page 200 in this one.
I don't know exactly when I started talking to self in the second person, but by the time
I ascended from puberty, the habit was firmly set and accepted.
I was going to ask you if that was autobiographical.
Yeah, probably, probably.
I would catch myself doing it, sometimes aloud and sometimes just to myself, to the point where
I no longer thought about it, right?
Only usually instead of saying self, although I say self now, which I didn't used to do.
Having written the book, now I say self, right?
I don't know.
It's life imitating art, but it's usually Norwood, you dummy.
It's Norwood this and Norwood that, and that's how I do, but I carry on the same kinds of
conversation that Gerard did, although I don't ask Norwood to do the same kinds of things
that he asked self to do.
I kind of know the answer to this, but we'll get it on tape anyway.
The two books have a lot of poetry, so apparently you write poetry yourself.
And I was going to ask you if maybe, since it's difficult to sell poetry or to publish
it in a lot of places, maybe this kind of lets you publish some of your books.
Oh yes, yes.
One of the modus operandi in the very beginning was to bootleg the poetry into the story.
In fact, it was the Tenderfoot cycle of poems which helped me formulate how I wanted to put
the story together.
And all the Tenderfoot poems aren't in there, fortunately.
But that was part of what I wanted to do in the books, because I thought, again, that was
something else that was, I was taking enough chances, I thought, I'll take one more.
I'll go ahead and try this and see what happens.
I've been writing poetry since I was nine, so I obviously believe in it in some form or
another.
So I thought, why not do that and see if we can make it work?
And I was very fortunate and found an editor who believed in it, after having talked to
several others who did not believe in it at all.
They won't go for this wussy stuff.
No, no, no.
In fact, Judy Lynn Del Rey, who I had known because I worked for Ballantyne, had read the
book.
She was the first one to read the manuscript.
And she wrote me this long, two-page detailed letter about why she hated the book.
And it didn't affect the way I felt about Judy Lynn, but she said, you know, you really
ought to just put this in the bottom drawer and write another one.
Well, of course, I couldn't do that.
But what I did was, eventually, I took Judy Lynn's letter back out of the drawer and read
it and re-read it and re-read it.
And then, in the query letters, trying to get people to read the manuscript, took all
those things that she hated and wrote them as if they were a list of positive attributes
for the book.
And so, in effect, Judy Lynn helped me sell the book, right?
She taught me, you know, she gave me the information I needed on how to sell the book.
So I took that whole list of things that she didn't like, said, this is what it is and
this is great.
And that's what got Karen Hossett Bantam to read it.
And she liked all those things that Judy Lynn did.
So it worked.
So I have to thank Judy Lynn Del Rey for helping me sell that book.
Great.
We talked to Ardeth Mayher last night and she said that she wrote poetry for many years.
She feels very strongly that having written poetry really helped her prose writing because
of the economy of words and that sort of thing.
Do you, has that helped you with your prose?
Do you think that experience of writing poetry?
I think so because if you write poetry regularly and try constantly to improve it and you're
constantly working with the language, you're constantly trying to squeeze from the language
as much meaning as possible.
So it makes you extremely cognizant of words and their meanings and their subtleties and shades
of meanings.
I think that it can, that writing poetry can also hurt your prose.
I think that you can, in fact, get too poetic.
You're trying to put too much in.
You're trying to make your prose too poetic.
I think it's, I marvel at some of the stuff that Gene Wolfe writes.
I mean, I think some of his, some of his prose just blows me away.
But at the same time, I think that sometimes he, he sticks with a level of writing that is almost
too poetic for the part of the story he's trying to tell that instead of doing it in rhythms,
he's so caught up in that rhythm, so caught up in that level, that poetic level that he
can't bring it down to a faster, cleaner action scene where you, you get out of that and you
sweep the reader along and then pull them back up to another poetic height.
And so I think, you know, I'm, this is not to criticize Gene Wolfe, but it's to say that
I think that because he is a poet and because he is so poetically involved with the language
that it has, it has detracted a little bit from what he might have otherwise done with
the story.
Of course, all this is envy on my part, because if I could, if I could write prose like Gene
Wolfe writes, I, you know, I would, I would be a very happy man.
I was reading the, the books, especially An Image of Voices, because Gerard's role changed
quite a bit in the second book, but it was, it was reminiscent, the situation was reminiscent
of Retief, Laumer's Retief.
Mm-hmm.
You read the Retief.
Years ago, yes.
Years ago.
And I tried not, I tried not to make Gerard not like Retief, right?
While still, you know, maintaining that, you know, intergalactic diplomat role.
I tried to make him a very different kind of diplomat.
But, but there were times, in fact, in the first draft, there are sections where it got
a little Retief-like kind of unconsciously, and then I had to go back and say, gee, I think
I read this somewhere before, and I didn't write it.
And then you have to go back and clean things up.
Pete, there were, they weren't characters, but the computers were a pretty big element in
the book, which I think is real.
I think the computers are going to be that important in the future.
But you seemed at home with computers and the jargon and that sort of thing.
So are you a computer freak?
The interesting part of that is that when I wrote those books, all my knowledge of computers
came from books, right?
I had no real firsthand experience with computers.
It was all from books and a lot of reading about them and what they could do and what they
couldn't do, what the latest developments were.
So having a year after I finished the third book, I now have my own home computer and I
do my word processing and all that.
And I think I would have a more difficult time now pulling it off the same way because
I know too many specifics that I didn't know before, right?
In a sense, I was safer with the generalities and approaching it that way.
And I was safe from the language and syntax of talking about computers.
And I've had several, one of the most pleasing things is reactions is I've had several computer
programmers and program analysts tell me that they really enjoyed the computer part, right?
Which means that I did my job as a writer.
I got through that part of it and yet I didn't slow everybody down with the technical ease.
So I made it believable for the people who knew and understood.
And I also made it acceptable to the people who didn't and aren't comfortable with that.
Are there any modern day precedents for the linguistic analysis by computers and the poetry
analysis by computers?
Very crude ones at this stage of the game.
But there's been work that's been done on that.
Several universities have done experimental programming with programming computers to write poetry,
programming computers to translate poetry.
And it's all at a very crude level.
So my extrapolation of that is a big stretch.
But I thought given the progress of technology that in 7,000 years it seemed reasonable that we'd figure out how to do it.
Might just do that.
Okay.
And whenever Manley was in the Fed Center rehab, he teaches a little class in writing.
And the reason was that it was to help the guests put some of their thoughts and feelings down on paper for therapy.
Is writing kind of therapeutic to you?
Yeah.
It's a form of therapy.
It's a form of catharsis.
It's a way of exercising your own demons.
You get to take this demon and give it to someone else and make them deal with it.
And then you get it out of your own head and you don't have to worry about it.
And then if it gets loose with them and runs over them, that's okay because it's them.
It's not you.
And so, yeah, it's always been that way for me.
Poetry was that way especially because it's an extremely emotional form when you're young.
And so it allows you a place to let go of those emotions where otherwise you might not have a socially acceptable outlet.
So it's always been that for me.
Has there ever been any precedent for psychologists using writing for people that have been through bad situations to exercise their demons?
Oh, yes.
Yes, yes.

In fact, I participated in a course that was partially based on that idea at the Federal Correctional Institute in Fort Worth where we got all these minimum security prisoners to work out some of their demons in creative writing.

And the whole thing on Pleasance when Gerard is in the rehab center is based on some things that we did when I was down at Fort Hood where they had a little program for long-term rehabilitation patients in the hospital at Fort Hood where they were doing some of that.
And I got to participate in a little bit of that program.
And that's where the idea came from.
Okay.
Okay.
Flexing the Warp Delta.
I guess I should, is it Sheree?
I call her Shereel.
That's it.
That's it.
Okay, good.
I realize that that's the first time I'd ever pronounced that word aloud.
Flexing the Warp dealt a great deal with Shereel's pregnancy.
And I've been through two pregnancies.
And it was very real.
And most science fiction books, I mean, you either use the auto-wool or something or it's no big deal.
But there was a lot of human emotion and love and that sort of thing.
And I hadn't seen it before.
Have you been through a firsthand pregnancy?
I mean, it's very realistically.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Through the pregnancy and through a miscarriage before it.
